headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the 21st Century Fox Second Quarter 2018 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the 21st Century Fox Second Quarter 2018 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Executive Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone. Welcome to our Second Quarter Fiscal 2018 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone. Welcome to our Second Quarter Fiscal 2018 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer. First, we'll give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter and we'll be happy to take questions from the investment community. 
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to 21st Century Fox business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended December 31, 2017, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. And these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings. Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. Please note that certain financial measures used in this call such segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release. and with that, I'm pleased to turn it over to Lachlan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. It's been nearly 2 months since we announced our new plans to create a dynamic new Fox and to merge the remainder of our business with Disney. Over these past weeks, it's clear that investors are embracing our p
componenttext:
Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. It's been nearly 2 months since we announced our new plans to create a dynamic new Fox and to merge the remainder of our business with Disney. Over these past weeks, it's clear that investors are embracing our plan. We firmly believe these transactions will unlock the full value of our iconic brands and better position all of our businesses to compete in a rapidly evolving media and entertainment landscape. But until the Disney deal closes sometime next year, we remain wholly focused on executing against the same growth strategies that made these transactions possible in the first place. Which brings us to the second fiscal quarter, where we deliver top line growth of 5% despite difficult comps, driven largely by double-digit growth at both our domestic and international cable network businesses. Importantly, this was underpinned by continued acceleration in domestic affiliate revenue. We drove a 12% year-over-year increase sequentially surpassing the 11% gain of the prior quarter. Our strategy has made a power growth through careful but steady investment in our core brands where we have made solid progress in strengthening our news, sports and entertainment businesses. 
Integral to the strategy is live sport. In fact, live sport has never been more important than it is today. This is why we are energized and excited about our recent agreement with the NFL to make FOX Sports the official home of Thursday Night Football for the next 5 years. NFL programming is hands-down the most powerful in all of media. And if you look at our decades long relationship with the league, I think you'll agree, having the most important sports rights over a longer term has always served us well. This new agreement joins our Sunday afternoon package with Thursday nights to concentrate America's football on Fox. This concentration affords us great monetization opportunities, including through our new expanded digital rights and creates a clear runway to further grow the value of our broadcast business, all key goals as we think about setting up a New Fox for the future. 
Broadly, this past fall, FOX Sports dominated viewership was 34% more live sports viewing than its next closest competitor. It achieved the goal it set at last year's upfront to be the #1 network in total football viewing and own the fall. For calendar year 2017, FOX Sports delivered a 21% gain over calendar 2016. Fox Sports entered 2018 as the leader in the most valuable type of programming, the leader in America's most popular sport and the dominant brand during the most valuable time of the year. Over news, Fox News closed calendar 2017 with its highest rated year ever, its second consecutive year as the most watched network on basic cable. Primetime changes drove growth in audience share across all key demographics. Likewise, FOXBusiness achieved its highest rated year ever in both total day and business day, beating CNBC in business day viewership. Turning to entertainment, where we continue to strengthen our output, we are creating new hits to drive even deeper audience engagement Fox Broadcasting has 4 of the top 5 new dramas of the season as well as 2 of the top 3 new comedies. In addition, our midseason is off to a promising start with the brilliant 911, a clear stand out. Cut to entertainment program has always been a critical part of SBC's lineup and that will not change with the New Fox. At our Film studio, the great work of our colleagues and creative partners was recognized with industry-leading 27 Academy award nominations. This is on top of more Golden Globe wins than any of our peers, showing the breadth and reach of our creative prowess, fueled by The Shape of Water, 3 billboards and The Greatest Showman. And we have a great sleight this calendar year with Deadpool 2 set for release in May, Battle Angel at Aleta in the summer and the next installment of the X-Men franchises, Dark Phoenix, set for later in the year. Looking ahead, we are focused on achieving our near-term growth plans while successfully completing our value-enhancing transactions. 
And with that, I'll hand over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon. Today, we reported our second quarter financial results, highlighted by 5% revenue growth resulting in over $8 billion in total revenues, a quarterly record for our current segments. This growth was driven by strong do
componenttext:
Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon. Today, we reported our second quarter financial results, highlighted by 5% revenue growth resulting in over $8 billion in total revenues, a quarterly record for our current segments. This growth was driven by strong double-digit affiliate fee increases at the cable networks, partially offset by lower advertising revenues at the Television segment. Segment EBITDA for the quarter of $1.44 billion was down 28% from last year. On an individual segment basis, increased cable segment contributions were more than offset by the expected impact of difficult comparisons at the Television segment and lower film entertainment results. From a bottom line perspective, income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $1.84 billion or $0.99 per share increased from the $0.46 per share reported in the prior year, and this is primarily due to a $1.3 billion or $0.72 per share benefit from the remeasurement of our net deferred tax liabilities as a result of the Tax Cuts and Job acts. Our adjusted EPS in the current quarter was $0.42 versus a comparable $0.53 in the prior year. 
So now turning to the performance of our operating segments for the quarter, the cable network segment reported EBITDA of $1.37 billion, a 3% increase over the prior year. Revenue growth of 11% was partially offset by a 15% increase in expenses from the higher volume of sporting events led by the earlier start of the NBA season at the RSNs, the timing of Cricket matches at STAR, the new Big Ten collegiate events as FS1 and new sublicensed sports product. This quarter's sublicensing had a 2 percentage point impact on revenue growth and a 3 percentage point impact on expense growth with no significant effect on earnings. 
Domestic cable revenues increased 10%, led by 12% affiliate fee growth, reflecting higher average rates across all of our domestic brands, led by national sports and news channels. Domestic advertising declined 3%, primarily reflecting the impact of lower general entertainment ratings from fewer hours of originals at FX. EBITDA at our domestic channels increased 1% over the prior year with a higher affiliate revenue mostly offset by the increased sports costs from the timing and volume of gains at the RSNs and the national sports channels. 
Reported international cable revenues grew 15%, with a 13% increase in reported affiliate revenue and a 14% increase in reported advertising revenue. International content and other revenues increased 30% due to the sublicensing of Latin American Soccer rights, which is fully offset in expenses. Reported international EBITDA contributions were up 8% from the prior year, reflecting the higher revenues being partially offset by expected higher programming costs, largely from the earlier timing of BCCI Cricket matches at STAR in India. 
At our Television segment, EBITDA was $56 million, 85% below last year. Revenues declined 6% as continued retransmission consent revenue growth was more than offset by expected advertising revenue declines, reflecting challenging comparisons to the prior year, which included local political revenues from the general election and the highest viewership for a World Series in over 2 decades as well as last year's incremental spectrum use revenue in one of our local TV markets. Also contributing to the revenue decline were the effects of lower NFL ratings, which were more than offset by the addition of college football on the network. Television segment expenses increased over the prior year, reflecting an increased volume of college and NFL football and MLB baseball games combined with normal contractual increases. 
At the Film segment, second quarter EBITDA of $131 million was $258 million below last year. This quarter included significant re-leasing costs for our holiday movie slate, including The Greatest Showman and Ferdinand as well as prerelease costs for Maze Runner. In all, we released 8 films in the quarter, 5 of which are Academy Award nominees compared to a much lighter released slate last year. 
Now from an overall balance sheet perspective, we ended the quarter with $5.8 billion in cash and $98 billion -- $19.8 billion in debt. And our capital allocation priority remains focused on the Sky acquisition. And finally, just a comment on tax. Because we have a June fiscal year, the impact of the U.S. tax act will blend in over 2 fiscal years. In this current fiscal year, our U.S. statutory rate will decline to a full year average of 28%. And then, beginning at the -- at next fiscal year, it will decline to the new 21% rate. At this point, we're expecting our normalized effective tax rate for fiscal '19 to be in the mid 20% range. 
With that, let me turn it over to James.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. And thanks, everyone, for joining today's call. In the first half of fiscal 2018, as you've seen, we've made of considerable progress. Our programming from scripted to nonfiction, sports and news continues to differenti
componenttext:
Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. And thanks, everyone, for joining today's call. In the first half of fiscal 2018, as you've seen, we've made of considerable progress. Our programming from scripted to nonfiction, sports and news continues to differentiate and fortify these brands. And our customers experience continues to improve as well. Our strategy of making our content more available, not less, is paying dividends, and we're driving more flexibility, more access both in and outside the home and a better advertising experience across the board. IP delivery of entertainment is driving a better environment for the business, and we are making strides. I want to highlight just a few advances. As of today, we are approaching 4 million Digital MVPD subscribers even as we're still in the early innings. Many of these services have yet to roll out distribution and marketing to important cities throughout the U.S. The growing subscriber contributions from these new entrants, which reflects 50% sequential growth from the September to December quarters, offset declines in the traditional distribution marketplace, maintaining our domestic subscriber levels. Our affiliate, Hulu, recently announced strong growth as well, crossing 17 million subscribers and notably adding more United States subscribers than Netflix in both of the last 2 quarters. Along with strong first half results as well, Sky recently announced streaming plans for key markets in Europe, developing cost-efficient platforms to extend the Sky Q and streaming businesses without the need of satellite DISH, driving growth opportunities in both existing and new markets. Let me update you on our proposed transactions, starting with Sky, which has moved forward to the next phase of the regulatory review progress. With the recent publication and provisional findings by the U.K. Competition and Markets Authority, we continue to engage constructively with the CMA to address their concerns ahead of their May 1 final report. We anticipate regulatory approval for our proposed Sky transaction by the end of June, as we've said earlier. And finally, on the New Fox and Disney, we are currently engaged in the planning process for the separation of the businesses with a view toward the integration of our assets at Disney and the establishment of the New Fox. We are convinced that the creation of these 2 dynamic media companies will set a path forward for our business us to thrive and realize their full potential and for our shareholders to benefit from compelling growth opportunities. 
In summary, we're continuing to make operational advances that bolster our competitive footing and position us for long-term growth. So with that, I think we'll go to your questions, Reed.

componenttext: I have one for James Lachlan about the NFL and one for John about taxes. So the NFL, you guys already have Sunday night. So the question is, what is another night of NFL give you that you have before? And could you talk about the digital rights received and how you're going to leverage digital rights and what are they? And for John, any update on what the tax rate would be for New Fox, assuming that deal gets done?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael. I'll jumped up it in. Lachlan can jump in as well I'm sure. The -- on the NFL, I think we've been -- I think Lachlan put it well in his opening comments we're really concentrating the NFL audience and NFL products on the FOX Network. I th
componenttext:
Thanks, Michael. I'll jumped up it in. Lachlan can jump in as well I'm sure. The -- on the NFL, I think we've been -- I think Lachlan put it well in his opening comments we're really concentrating the NFL audience and NFL products on the FOX Network. I think it is very attractive. I think when you look at the licensing that the NFL has undertaken, with expanding the Thursday night, and we've talked in the past about what fragmentation can do to the overall -- audience of each individual day, we the right answer there is really to concentrate that audience and to have Fox really be the clear leader in NFL broadcasting with the product as powerful as it is. So we think that's pretty attractive to have the extra night of football and it's a powerful platform for the network, both in terms of other promotions and promoting other nights and other programs. But in general, it's a scarcity value of large audiences coming together around national events continues to rise. We really want Fox to be the home of that kind of compelling product. 
And then with respect to the digital rights, I think just in summary, the new agreement gives us much more flexibility in terms of exploiting those rights, some of which on a nonexistent basis. Others definitely gives us more flexibility to explore the rights and bring the product to our customers in new ways, both on a direct-to-consumer basis and over-the-top and on new devices.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that's right, James. With the NFL I think I said I might have said in my prepared comments that we have 3 of the 5 top shows on the United States Television with the addition of the Thursday Night Football. We think that consolidating Thursd
componenttext: Look, I think that's right, James. With the NFL I think I said I might have said in my prepared comments that we have 3 of the 5 top shows on the United States Television with the addition of the Thursday Night Football. We think that consolidating Thursday Night Football under 1 network as opposed to 2 gives us a great opportunity to actually grow the ratings of Thursday Night Football. And we've already seen sort of good momentum behind the network. I think we finished January as the #1 network on Television. We're the only network with growth of about 15% growth in January. We liked our fall launches and our midseason. Our shows, obviously, I mentioned, are 911 and also the 4 has been a good reality show for us. We actually feel we've got momentum and the addition of Thursday Night Football will strengthen that as well.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Michael, it's John. The tax rate is really 2 parts to the answer. One is as a wholly domestic company, New Fox's rate will be close to the statutory federal and state and local rates on the mid-'20s, but it's important from a cash standpoint to recognize,
componenttext: Michael, it's John. The tax rate is really 2 parts to the answer. One is as a wholly domestic company, New Fox's rate will be close to the statutory federal and state and local rates on the mid-'20s, but it's important from a cash standpoint to recognize, as we said in the call we announced Disney that New Fox will also have a substantial tax shield over 15 years. So its cash rate will be substantially below that statutory rate.

componenttext: Let me just start with for the development for this coming fall, the way the development process works, we're already sort of deeply into our sort of development cycle. We started to order new pilots, of which just been through a number of the scripts and the orders and they're very excited about that process is already underway. So with New Fox, you will see diversification in terms of who we are buying content from. But that will really become the season after this coming season. You'll see that start to change more dramatically.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then maybe separately the Thursday night deal, can you talk about broadly about your view on sports rights? The fragmentation of viewers that you guys referenced, how are you thinking about rights as loss leaders, particularly as other deals ren
componenttext: Okay, and then maybe separately the Thursday night deal, can you talk about broadly about your view on sports rights? The fragmentation of viewers that you guys referenced, how are you thinking about rights as loss leaders, particularly as other deals renew across the rest of the portfolio in the coming years?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Look, I think, John, it's always about choices and you're always looking at what kind of, a, the cost of rights and what you can afford to do, what you think you're going to make a return on a standalone basis as well as thinking about them I guess I woul
componenttext: Look, I think, John, it's always about choices and you're always looking at what kind of, a, the cost of rights and what you can afford to do, what you think you're going to make a return on a standalone basis as well as thinking about them I guess I wouldn't say loss leader, but there's investments you make for a period of time to establish an event, to gather the audience, but also use it as a platform for promoting other thing. So I think around the world, we look at sports rights as something pretty straightforward, we just have to make judgment calls in each option, in each situation and with each package of rights that come up. And that can be from the IPL in India, which we are commencing broadcasting for the first time this year, to Soccer and European football rights to the NFL or baseball here. So each time you have to look at it and think about the overall balance of investment and how you go forward. I think with respect to the overall fragmentation of viewing kind of generally, I think the value of a concentrated audience is very high, even if the absolute number of viewers may be a little bit lower as the fragmentation impacts, the scarcity value of those events is tremendous. And advertisers are -- remain very attracted to that. So we think it's an important part of the portfolio, but you would never make a blanket assumption about prices, about which events and what you're doing going forward because you have to look at it on a case by case basis. As you've seen in the past where we've walked away from things, waited until the structure of a package was just right. And then been more confident investing in it and that's the way we're looking at it.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: I'll -- maybe I can answer the New Fox question and James can address STAR. Absolutely Fox we see a great potential to increase our retransmission revenue quite aggressively. We think that for 2 reasons. One, obviously, some of the focus and investment of
componenttext: I'll -- maybe I can answer the New Fox question and James can address STAR. Absolutely Fox we see a great potential to increase our retransmission revenue quite aggressively. We think that for 2 reasons. One, obviously, some of the focus and investment of support and with the new NFL Thursday night package. But also I think just as being a more focused company with fewer channels in our bundle, we will be able to drive our retrans for the stations quite aggressively.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think just on that really it's really still -- it's still a growth trajectory in terms of getting to what we think is a fair price, given the strength of the network, the strength of the stations and the size of that audience and its leadership. So
componenttext: Yes, I think just on that really it's really still -- it's still a growth trajectory in terms of getting to what we think is a fair price, given the strength of the network, the strength of the stations and the size of that audience and its leadership. So even irrespective, we think there's good opportunities there. And with respect to STAR yes, halfway to the fiscal year, always there's ups and downs in these things, but we see nothing at this point to make us feel any differently about the targets, both in the short-term and the medium-term. And we're thinking about the long-term as well, so we're very excited about the balance of the year, STAR free to air channel has done very, very well and has launched this year. And we'll get there or thereabouts.

You've alluded about possibly launching a direct to consumer service. Maybe you could talk about that and TV station acquisition but any way you want to address that question.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Jessica, I think the first thing to remember we got a little ways to go here. We got regulatory approval to be obtained and we're very focused on that. We're very focused on closing all the transactions that we have up in the air, be it Sky in the near te
componenttext: Jessica, I think the first thing to remember we got a little ways to go here. We got regulatory approval to be obtained and we're very focused on that. We're very focused on closing all the transactions that we have up in the air, be it Sky in the near term and a little bit further out Disney transaction and the stand up and separation of the New Fox. So we're focused on those things very much. But until we get there, we're very much operating this business at a very -- at a high velocity. And in a mode around building each business and each brand as best we can as we would have anyway. So I think ahead of closing, you have to operate on a business as usual, basis, and you have to try to make the right decisions for each business and each man there. So for example, we continue to build our capabilities and direct to consumer. We've revamped all of our major over-the-top apps in the United States and, in some cases, outside with Fox Plus in Latin America and, for example, NatGeo 1 which launched in Australia recently. So we continue to push the pace on that. And I think as we get closer to closing, right and the separation, then you have to establish the kind of right path for each different chunk. But in the meantime, I think we just continue to go. We're seeing really good progress, great customer numbers there, really great customer engagement. As I mentioned, my comments the customer experience just gets better and better as we've invested in this capability in rolling out new features and new upgrades to all of those things. So we continue to do that. And with respect to other sorts of opportunities, you mentioned stations, et cetera, we have to be open-minded and do the right thing for the long-term value in the business. And none of the pending transactions change that. We think we are on a pretty good course and we'll continue to be.

componenttextpreview: And Jessica, look, we've been talking for 2 years about increased competition from Digital MVPDs starting to generate real growth in the marketplace and competition always creates growth and innovation, that's why we believe in it, and we've enabled a lot
componenttext: And Jessica, look, we've been talking for 2 years about increased competition from Digital MVPDs starting to generate real growth in the marketplace and competition always creates growth and innovation, that's why we believe in it, and we've enabled a lot of these new competitors to really get into the market. When we talk about licensing our product in a way that makes our content and our brands more available and not less, it's all about enabling the competition. So we're really seeing that come through now, and you're seeing it overall in the market. It's really not done. There's a lot to play for going forward, but we are very encouraged by the growth of these new platforms and encouraged by that sector generally, for the sector generally, on the basis of that.

componenttext: So let me -- it's John, let me cover both for John's. First the NFL as James referred to earlier, this is all about choices. So as we look at the NFL it's against what our plans were. So in the first year, we expect to make an investment into Thursday package and, thereafter, as against our plans, we feel we'll be in a very comfortable place as against where we thought we'd be. As it relates to the sports and news channels, I don't know we want to actually call out any 1 particular channel. We increasingly are selling these channels as a group. We do have isolated deals here and there, but every single channel performed very well for us in the quarter and continues to.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back a little bit to the Thursday Night Football deal in conjunction with the Disney deal. And the question is really about scale in sports. With the Disney deal, there's, obviously, some measure of slowing down by giving them the RSNs and
componenttext: I wanted to go back a little bit to the Thursday Night Football deal in conjunction with the Disney deal. And the question is really about scale in sports. With the Disney deal, there's, obviously, some measure of slowing down by giving them the RSNs and you're following that up with a bigger check for big NFL rights. And I'm just wondering, should we read from this that the RSNs really didn't contribute to scale that they were such a different business that it doesn't really give you any more leverage for fee recovery for big sports rights or to be able to kind of economic case for them? Or is the idea that scale is important for these big sports rights, may be less important than some of us might have thought?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Look, I think with respect to the rationale around the separation of the RSNs and New Fox, et cetera, I mean it's really a question of organizing all of the brands in the business in the way that we think are going to be most attractive from a long-term v
componenttext: Look, I think with respect to the rationale around the separation of the RSNs and New Fox, et cetera, I mean it's really a question of organizing all of the brands in the business in the way that we think are going to be most attractive from a long-term value perspective, both with respect to the merged Fox Disney company as well as the New Fox. I think the economic performance of RSNs has been tremendous. But also remember that they have their own sets of rights, local rights. It's a very different market. They don't really compete with the rest, so it's as a standalone business driving audience and driving engagement there, we continue to think it's a very attractive business, and that's why it was a very attractive opportunity to include those in the merger with Disney. That said, the national sports market, which is pretty distinct in terms of rights, terms of how you do it, et cetera, is one we also believe in. As you can see, with the rapid growth of FOX Sports 1 and 2, the Big Ten Network and we're excited about that that's why we started Fox Sports only a few years ago.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, if I could just follow up I mean I think one of the questions has been the durability of companies like yours to pay higher sports rights as others might come in, the Internet companies. I was just wondering if you think scaling up is important to b
componenttext: Okay, if I could just follow up I mean I think one of the questions has been the durability of companies like yours to pay higher sports rights as others might come in, the Internet companies. I was just wondering if you think scaling up is important to be able to compete with that -- compete in that future? Or maybe that's less important for you guys as a strategic priority right now?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not so sure it's the future. I think actually it's the present. If you look at the IPL auction in India last year, we were competing very aggressively with Facebook in that auction. And we have a great platform there. It's a great platform for m
componenttext: Well, I'm not so sure it's the future. I think actually it's the present. If you look at the IPL auction in India last year, we were competing very aggressively with Facebook in that auction. And we have a great platform there. It's a great platform for monetization. It's a great platform for reaching audience, and we were able to win that auction. But in all of these places, it's a question really of making choices, and that's why you don't have to say you don't have to be all in on every set of rights and pay whatever it takes. And I don't -- doesn't really matter who's bidding. People have to make economic choices around the value of these rights, the value of these products. So we like our ability to compete across the board with these brands with a variety and the diversity of rights that I think we've proven ourselves in terms of being able to put together really compelling packages there, but it's never a question of all or nothing. You have to make choices and sometimes, you don't think some of the work as much as somebody else does, and you push the business or steer the business in a different direction.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: 2 questions, John. On the Disney deal, now that the tax reform has been signed into law, can you update us at all on dividend payment that New Fox will be making the 21st Century at the close for the spin? And then how that relates to sort of the balance
componenttext: 2 questions, John. On the Disney deal, now that the tax reform has been signed into law, can you update us at all on dividend payment that New Fox will be making the 21st Century at the close for the spin? And then how that relates to sort of the balance sheet and the debt level at New Fox once this all closed? I know this moving pieces but now, that we have the tax law signed, I was hoping you could give us some clarity. And then just at the risk of beating Thursday Night Football to death, you guys have invested a lot in ad tech to try to monetize viewers better. But certainly the consensus for you is the ad revenues on the NFL are flat to down looking forward, given the ratings trajectory. I'm just wondering if you have a different perspective based on what you've been able to do with TrueX and other products to try to monetize large live audiences and maybe we're being too conservative in our outlook on the advertising side of NFL.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben. It's John, I'll start. It depends on how you value New Fox to answer this question. But in my own mind, the tax liability that will result from the spin of New Fox is somewhere in the plus or minus so now with tax reform of $6 billion. And re
componenttext: Thanks, Ben. It's John, I'll start. It depends on how you value New Fox to answer this question. But in my own mind, the tax liability that will result from the spin of New Fox is somewhere in the plus or minus so now with tax reform of $6 billion. And remember, there is always -- as part of the deal, minimum debt level at New Fox of $6.5 billion. So as a result, I think you should assume we will be making a minimum distribution. And the spread between the tax and the debt is accomplished or compensated for by an adjustment to the exchange ratio. So -- and every -- and low, pick a point on what you think the equity trading value is for every dollar at that market value moves one way or another, it's about $425 million of cash tax.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then on the point about advertising, look, I think we're making really good progress on nonlinear advertising and new advertising formats in the linear stream as well. So I feel -- we feel pretty good about that. I think clearly, the ratings did impac
componenttext: And then on the point about advertising, look, I think we're making really good progress on nonlinear advertising and new advertising formats in the linear stream as well. So I feel -- we feel pretty good about that. I think clearly, the ratings did impact revenue, the number of impressions we can deliver to advertisers is always something we have to do well or we have some pretty difficult comparisons, as John mentioned, in this year-on-year period. But we actually feel reasonably good about it and I think actually the promise of streaming environment is 1 there -- or even in linear broadcasting on sports, for example, having a nonlinear, very data-driven advertising platform seeing it underneath that and being able to monetize that audience is hugely attractive. And we see that starting to bear fruit, but it's still not an enormous part of the audience that's consuming nonlinear product on digital streaming prop Florence. So that something that as that grows, we think that the yields from a minute by minute, customer by customer basis will continue to improve. We certainly see that, for example, in the Hulu streams, where we just have dramatically better monetization Hulu owned and operated apps than we do, for example, on the traditional MVPD distribution, which is some -- is encouraging in terms of leveling off and equalizing over the next number of years, which we think is very possible.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the 21st Century Fox Second Quarter 2018 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the 21st Century Fox Second Quarter 2018 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Executive Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone. Welcome to our second quarter fiscal 2018 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone. Welcome to our second quarter fiscal 2018 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer. First, we'll give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, and we'll be happy to take questions from the investment community.
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to 21st Century Fox's business and strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended December 31, 2017, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ. And these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings.
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. Please note that certain financial measures used in this call such as segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release.
And with that, I'm pleased to turn it over to Lachlan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. It's been nearly 2 months since we announced our plans to create a dynamic new Fox and to merge the remainder of our business with Disney. Over these past weeks, it's clear that investors are embracing our plan.
componenttext:
Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. It's been nearly 2 months since we announced our plans to create a dynamic new Fox and to merge the remainder of our business with Disney. Over these past weeks, it's clear that investors are embracing our plan. We firmly believe these transactions will unlock the full value of our iconic brands and better position all of our businesses to compete in a rapidly evolving media and entertainment landscape. But until the Disney deal closes sometime next year, we remain wholly focused on executing against the same growth strategies that made these transactions possible in the first place. Which brings us to the second fiscal quarter where we deliver top line growth of 5% despite difficult comps, driven largely by double-digit growth at both our domestic and international cable network businesses. Importantly, this was underpinned by continued acceleration in domestic affiliate revenue. We drove a 12% year-over-year increase, sequentially surpassing the 11% gain of the prior quarter. Our strategy has made a power [indiscernible] growth through careful but steady investment in our core brands where we have made solid progress in strengthening our news, sport and entertainment businesses.
Integral to the strategy is live sport. In fact, live sport has never been more important than it is today. This is why we are energized and excited about our recent agreement with the NFL to make FOX Sports the official home of Thursday Night Football for the next 5 years. NFL programming is hands-down the most powerful in all of media. And if you look at our decades-long relationship with the league, I think you'll agree, having the most important sports rights over a longer term has always served us well.
This new agreement joins our Sunday afternoon package with Thursday nights to concentrate America's football on Fox. This concentration affords us great monetization opportunities, including through our new expanded digital rights, and creates a clear runway to further grow the value of our broadcast business, all key goals as we think about setting up the New Fox for the future.
Broadly, this past fall, FOX Sports dominated viewership with 34% more live sports viewing than its next closest competitor. It achieved the goal it set at last year's upfront to be the #1 network in total football viewing and owned the fall. For calendar year 2017, FOX Sports delivered a 21% gain over calendar 2016. Fox Sports enters 2018 as the leader in the most valuable type of programming, the leader in America's most popular sport and the dominant brand during the most valuable time of the year.
Over on news. Fox News closed calendar 2017 with its highest rated year ever, its second consecutive year as the most watched network on basic cable. Primetime changes drove growth in audience share across all key demographics. Likewise, FOX Business achieved its highest rated year ever in both total day and business day, beating CNBC in business day viewership.
Turning to entertainment, where we continue to strengthen our output, we are creating new hits to drive even deeper audience engagement. Fox Broadcasting has 4 of the top 5 new dramas of the season as well as 2 of the top 3 new comedies. In addition, our mid-season is off to a promising start with the brilliant 911, a clear standout.  Cut-through entertainment programming has always been a critical part of FBC's lineup, and that will not change with the New Fox.
At our film studio, the great work of our colleagues and creative partners was recognized with industry-leading 27 Academy Award nominations. This is on top of more Golden Globe wins than any of our peers, showing the breadth and reach of our creative prowess, fueled by The Shape of Water, Three Billboards and The Greatest Showman. And we have a great slate this calendar year, with Deadpool 2 set for release in May, Battle Angel Alita in the summer and the next installment of the X-Men franchises, Dark Phoenix, set for later in the year. Looking ahead, we are focused on achieving our near-term growth plans while successfully completing our value-enhancing transactions.
And with that, I'll hand over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon. Today, we reported our second quarter financial results, highlighted by 5% revenue growth, resulting in over $8 billion in total revenues, a quarterly record for our current segments. This growth was driven by strong d
componenttext:
Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon. Today, we reported our second quarter financial results, highlighted by 5% revenue growth, resulting in over $8 billion in total revenues, a quarterly record for our current segments. This growth was driven by strong double-digit affiliate fee increases at the cable networks, partially offset by lower advertising revenues at the Television segment.
Segment EBITDA for the quarter of $1.44 billion was down 28% from last year. On an individual segment basis, increased Cable segment contributions were more than offset by the expected impact of difficult comparisons at the Television segment and lower Filmed Entertainment results.
From a bottom line perspective, income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $1.84 billion or $0.99 per share increased from the $0.46 per share reported in the prior year, and this is primarily due to a $1.3 billion or $0.72 per share benefit from the remeasurement of our net deferred tax liabilities as a result of the Tax Cuts and Job Acts. Our adjusted EPS in the current quarter was $0.42 versus a comparable $0.53 in the prior year.
So now turning to the performance of our operating segments for the quarter. The Cable Network segment reported EBITDA of $1.37 billion, a 3% increase over the prior year. Revenue growth of 11% was partially offset by a 15% increase in expenses from a higher volume of sporting events, led by the earlier start of the NBA season at the RSNs, the timing of cricket matches at STAR, the new Big Ten collegiate events at FS1 and new sublicensed sports product. This quarter's sublicensing had a 2 percentage point impact on revenue growth and a 3 percentage point impact on expense growth with no significant effect on earnings.
Domestic cable revenues increased 10%, led by 12% affiliate fee growth, reflecting higher average rates across all of our domestic brands, led by national sports and news channels. Domestic advertising declined 3%, primarily reflecting the impact of lower general entertainment ratings from fewer hours of originals at FX. EBITDA at our domestic channels increased 1% over the prior year, with the higher affiliate revenue mostly offset by the increased sports costs from the timing and volume of gains at the RSNs and the national sports channels.
Reported international cable revenues grew 15% with a 13% increase in reported affiliate revenue and a 14% increase in reported advertising revenue. International content and other revenues increased 30% due to the sublicensing of Latin American soccer rights, which is fully offset in expenses. Reported international EBITDA contributions were up 8% from the prior year, reflecting the higher revenues, being partially offset by expected higher programming costs, largely from the earlier timing of BCCI cricket matches at STAR in India.
At our Television segment, EBITDA was $56 million, 85% below last year. Revenues declined 6% as continued retransmission consent revenue growth was more than offset by expected advertising revenue declines, reflecting challenging comparisons to the prior year, which included local political revenues from the general election and the highest viewership for a World Series in over 2 decades as well as last year's incremental spectrum use revenue in one of our local TV markets.
Also contributing to the revenue decline were the effects of lower NFL ratings, which were more than offset by the addition of college football on the network. Television segment expenses increased over the prior year, reflecting an increased volume of college and NFL football and MLB baseball games combined with normal contractual increases.
At the Film segment, second quarter EBITDA of $131 million was $258 million below last year. This quarter included significant releasing costs for our holiday movie slate, including The Greatest Showman and Ferdinand as well as prerelease costs for Maze Runner. In all, we released 8 films in the quarter, 5 of which are Academy Award nominees, compared to a much lighter release slate last year.
Now from an overall balance sheet perspective, we ended the quarter with $5.8 billion in cash and $19.8 billion in debt. And our capital allocation priority remains focused on the Sky acquisition.
And finally, just a comment on tax. Because we have a June fiscal year, the impact of the U.S. tax act will blend in over 2 fiscal years. In this current fiscal year, our U.S. statutory rate will decline to a full year average of 28%. And then beginning at next fiscal year, it will decline to the new 21% rate. At this point, we're expecting our normalized effective tax rate for fiscal '19 to be in the mid-20% range.
With that, let me turn it over to James.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. And thanks, everyone, for joining today's call. In the first half of fiscal 2018, as you've seen, we made really considerable progress. Our programming, I think, from scripted to nonfiction, sports and news continues to
componenttext:
Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. And thanks, everyone, for joining today's call. In the first half of fiscal 2018, as you've seen, we made really considerable progress. Our programming, I think, from scripted to nonfiction, sports and news continues to differentiate and fortify these brands. And our customers' experience continues to improve as well. Our strategy of making our content more available, not less, is paying dividends, and we're driving more flexibility, more access both in and outside the home and a better advertising experience across the board. IP delivery of entertainment is driving a better environment for the business, and we are making strides. I want to highlight just a few advances.
As of today, we are approaching 4 million Digital MVPD subscribers even if we're still in the very early innings. Many of these services have yet to roll out distribution and marketing to important cities throughout the U.S. The growing subscriber contributions from these new entrants, which reflects 50% sequential growth from the September to December quarters, offset declines in the traditional distribution marketplace, maintaining our domestic subscriber levels. Our affiliate, Hulu, recently announced strong growth as well, crossing 17 million subscribers and, notably, adding more United States subscribers than Netflix in both of the last 2 quarters. Along with strong first half results as well, Sky recently announced streaming plans for key markets in Europe, developing cost-efficient platforms to extend the Sky Q and streaming businesses without the need of a satellite dish, driving growth opportunities in both existing and new markets.
Let me update you on our proposed transactions, starting with Sky, which has moved forward to the next phase of the regulatory review progress. With the recent publication of provisional findings by the U.K. Competition and Markets Authority, we'll continue to engage constructively with the CMA to address their concerns ahead of their May 1 final report. We anticipate regulatory approval for our proposed Sky transaction by the end of June, as we've said earlier.
And finally, on the New Fox and Disney, we're currently engaged in the planning process for the separation of the businesses with a view toward the integration of our assets at Disney and the establishment of the New Fox. We're convinced that the creation of these 2 dynamic media companies will set a path forward for our businesses to thrive and realize their full potential and for our shareholders to benefit from compelling growth opportunities.
In summary, we're continuing to make operational advances that bolster our competitive footing and position us for long-term growth.
So with that, I think we'll go to your questions, Reed.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: I have one for James or Lachlan about the NFL and one for John about taxes. So the NFL, you guys already have Sunday night. So the question is, what does another night of NFL give you that you had before? And then could you talk about the digital rights r
componenttext: I have one for James or Lachlan about the NFL and one for John about taxes. So the NFL, you guys already have Sunday night. So the question is, what does another night of NFL give you that you had before? And then could you talk about the digital rights received and how you're going to leverage the digital rights and what are they? And then for John, any update on what the tax rate would be for New Fox assuming that deal gets done?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael. I'll jump up it in. Lachlan can jump in as well, I'm sure. The -- look, on the NFL, I think we've been -- I think Lachlan put it well in his opening comments, we're really concentrating the NFL audience and NFL products on the Fox Network
componenttext: Thanks, Michael. I'll jump up it in. Lachlan can jump in as well, I'm sure. The -- look, on the NFL, I think we've been -- I think Lachlan put it well in his opening comments, we're really concentrating the NFL audience and NFL products on the Fox Network because, I mean, we think it's very attractive. I think when you look at the licensing that the NFL has undertaken with expanding the Thursday night, and we've talked in the past about what fragmentation can do to the overall -- the audience of each individual day, we think the right answer there is actually to concentrate that audience and to have Fox really be the clear leader in NFL broadcasting with a product as powerful as it is. So we think that's pretty attractive to have the extra night of football, and it's a powerful platform for the network, both in terms of other promotions and promoting other nights and other programs. But in general, the scarcity value of large audiences coming together around national events continues to rise. We really want Fox to be the home of that kind of compelling product. And then with respect to the digital rights, I think just in summary, the new agreement gives us much more flexibility in terms of exploiting those rights, some of which on a nonexistent basis, others differently, but it gives us more flexibility to exploit the rights and really bring the product to our customers in new ways, both on a direct-to-consumer basis and over-the-top and on new devices.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that's right, James. With the NFL, well, I think I said -- I might have said in my prepared comments that we have 3 of the 5 top sort of shows on United States television with the addition of the Thursday Night Football. We think that consol
componenttext: Look, I think that's right, James. With the NFL, well, I think I said -- I might have said in my prepared comments that we have 3 of the 5 top sort of shows on United States television with the addition of the Thursday Night Football. We think that consolidating Thursday Night Football under one network as opposed to 2 gives us a great opportunity to actually grow the ratings of Thursday Night Football. And we've already seen sort of good momentum behind the network. I think we finished January as the #1 network in television. We're the only network with growth of about 15% growth in January. We liked our fall launches and our mid-season. Our shows, obviously, I mentioned, are 911 and also The Four has been a good reality show for us. So we actually feel we've got momentum, and the addition of Thursday Night Football will strengthen that as well.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Michael, it's John. The tax rate is really 2 parts to the answer. One is as a wholly domestic company, New Fox's rate will be close to the statutory federal and state and local rates on the mid-20s, but it's important from a cash standpoint to recognize,
componenttext: Michael, it's John. The tax rate is really 2 parts to the answer. One is as a wholly domestic company, New Fox's rate will be close to the statutory federal and state and local rates on the mid-20s, but it's important from a cash standpoint to recognize, as we said in the call we announced Disney that New Fox will also have a substantial tax shield over 15 years. So its cash rate will be substantially below that statutory rate.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018

componenttext: Just -- how did the merger -- how are you thinking about programming and scheduling the network? Do you start to diversify, I guess, New Fox away from the Fox studio this fall in terms of suppliers? Or do you wait until the expected close? And I guess with what seems like the likelihood of further consolidation, can you talk about the probability of Fox ultimately supplying itself content in any of the key dayparts?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Let me just start with -- for the development for this coming fall, the way the development process works, we're already sort of deeply into our sort of development cycle, just started to order new pilots, of which I've just been through a number of the s
componenttext: Let me just start with -- for the development for this coming fall, the way the development process works, we're already sort of deeply into our sort of development cycle, just started to order new pilots, of which I've just been through a number of the scripts and the orders, and they're very excited. But that process is already well underway. So with New Fox, you will see a diversification in terms of who we are buying content from, but that will really become the season after this coming season. You'll see that start to change more dramatically.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe separately, the Sunday Thursday night deal, can you talk more broadly about your view on sports rights? With the fragmentation of viewers that you guys referenced, how are you thinking about rights as loss leaders, particularly as oth
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe separately, the Sunday Thursday night deal, can you talk more broadly about your view on sports rights? With the fragmentation of viewers that you guys referenced, how are you thinking about rights as loss leaders, particularly as other deals renew across the rest of the portfolio in the coming years?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Look, I think, John, it's always about choices, and you're always looking at what kind of, a, the cost of rights and what you can afford to do, what you think you're going to make a return on, on a stand-alone basis as well as thinking about them -- I gue
componenttext: Look, I think, John, it's always about choices, and you're always looking at what kind of, a, the cost of rights and what you can afford to do, what you think you're going to make a return on, on a stand-alone basis as well as thinking about them -- I guess I wouldn't say loss leader, but there's investments you make for a period of time to establish an event, to gather the audience, but also use it as a platform for promoting other things. So I think around the world, we look at sports rights as something pretty straightforward. We just have to make judgment calls in each auction, in each situation and with each package of rights that come up. And that can be from the IPL in India, which we're commencing broadcasting for the first time this year, to soccer and European football rights, to the NFL or baseball here. So each time, you have to look at it and think about the overall balance of investment and how you go forward. I think with respect to the overall fragmentation of viewing kind of generally, I think the value of a concentrated audience is very high. Even if the absolute number of viewers may be a little bit lower as the fragmentation impacts, the scarcity value of those events is tremendous. And advertisers are -- remain very attracted to that. So we think it's an important part of the portfolio, but you would never make a blanket assumption about prices, about which events and what you're doing going forward because you have to look at it on a case-by-case basis. As you've seen in the past where we've walked away from things or waited until the structure of a package was just right and then been more confident investing in it, and that's the way we're looking at it.

componenttext: I'll -- maybe I can answer the New Fox question, and James can address STAR. Absolutely, New Fox, we see a great potential to increase our retransmission revenue quite aggressively. We think that for 2 reasons. One, obviously, some of the focus and investment and support and with the new NFL Thursday night package. But also I think just as being a more focused company with fewer channels in our bundle, we'll be able to drive our retrans for the stations quite aggressively.

componenttext: Yes, I think just on that, it's really just still -- it's still a growth trajectory in terms of getting to what we think is a fair price given the strength of the network, the strength of the stations and the size of that audience and its leadership. So even irrespective, we think there's good opportunities there. And with respect to STAR, yes, halfway through the fiscal year, always there's ups and downs in these things, but we see nothing at this point to make us feel any differently about the targets, both in the short term and the medium term. And we're thinking about the long term as well, so we're very excited about the balance of the year. Star Bharat, the big free-to-air channel, has done very, very well and has launched this year. And we'll get there, thereabouts.

componenttext: Kind of a bigger picture, what do you see as the biggest challenges and opportunities between now and closing with Disney? You've alluded about possibly launching a direct-to-consumer service. Maybe you could talk about that and TV station acquisitions, but any way you want to address that question.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Jessica, I think -- look, I think the first thing to remember is that we've got a little ways to go here. We've got regulatory approval to be obtained, and we're very focused on that. We're very focused on closing all the transactions that we have up in t
componenttext: Jessica, I think -- look, I think the first thing to remember is that we've got a little ways to go here. We've got regulatory approval to be obtained, and we're very focused on that. We're very focused on closing all the transactions that we have up in the air, be it Sky in the near term and a little bit further out, the Disney transaction and the standup and separation of the New Fox. So we're focused on those things very much. But until we get there, we're very much operating this business at a very -- at a high velocity and in a mode around building each business and each brand as best we can as we would have anyway. So I think ahead of closing, you have to operate on a business as usual basis and you have to try to make the right decisions for each business and each brand there. So for example, we continue to build our capabilities in direct-to-consumer. We've revamped all of our major over-the-top apps in the United States and, in some cases, outside with Fox Plus in Latin America and, for example, Nat Geo 1, which launched in Australia recently. So we continue to push the pace on that. And I think as we get closer to closing, right, and the separation, then you have to establish the kind of glide path for each different chunk. But in the meantime, I think we just continue to go. We're seeing really good progress, great customer numbers there, really great customer engagement. As I mentioned in my comments, the customer experience just gets better and better as we've invested in this capability in rolling out new features and new upgrades to all of those things. So we continue to do that. And with respect to other sorts of opportunities, you mentioned stations, et cetera, we have to be open-minded and do the right thing for the long-term value in the business. And none of the pending transactions change that. We think we're on a pretty good course, and we'll continue to be.

componenttext: And, Jessica, look, we've been talking for 2 years about increased competition from Digital MVPDs starting to generate real growth in the marketplace, and competition always creates growth and innovation. That's why we believe in it, and we've enabled a lot of these new competitors to really get into the market. When we talk about licensing our product in a way that makes our content and our brands more available and not less, it's all about enabling that competition. So we're really seeing that come through now, and you're seeing it overall in the market. It's not -- it's certainly not done. There's a lot to play for going forward, but we're very encouraged by the growth of these new platforms and encouraged by that sector, generally -- for the sector, generally, on the basis of that.

componenttext: So let me -- it's John. Let me cover both for you, John. First, on the NFL, as James referred to earlier, this is all about choices. headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back a little bit to the Thursday Night Football deal in conjunction with the Disney deal. And the question is really about scale in sports. With the Disney deal, there's obviously some measure of slowing down by giving them the RSNs, and y
componenttext: I wanted to go back a little bit to the Thursday Night Football deal in conjunction with the Disney deal. And the question is really about scale in sports. With the Disney deal, there's obviously some measure of slowing down by giving them the RSNs, and you're following that up with a bigger check for big NFL rights. And I'm just wondering, should we read from this that the RSNs really didn't contribute to scale, that they were such a different business, that it doesn't really give you any more leverage for fee recovery for big sports rights or to be able to kind of make an economic case for them? Or is the idea that scale is important for these big sports rights, maybe less important than some of us might have thought?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Look, I think what we're -- with respect to the rationale around the separation of the RSNs and New Fox, et cetera, I mean, it's really a question of organizing all of the brands in the businesses in a way that we think are going to be most attractive fro
componenttext: Look, I think what we're -- with respect to the rationale around the separation of the RSNs and New Fox, et cetera, I mean, it's really a question of organizing all of the brands in the businesses in a way that we think are going to be most attractive from a long-term value perspective, both with respect to the merged Fox Disney company as well as the New Fox. I think the economic performance of the RSNs has been tremendous. But also remember that they have their own set of rights, local rights. It's a very different market. They don't really compete with the rest. So it's -- as a stand-alone business driving audience and driving engagement there, we continue to think it's a very attractive business, and that's why we think it was a very attractive opportunity to include those in the merger with Disney. That said, the national sports market, which is pretty distinct in terms of rights, in terms of how you do it, et cetera, is one that we also believe in. As you can see, with the rapid growth of FOX Sports 1 and 2, the Big Ten Network, and we're excited about that, that's why we started FOX Sports 1 only a few years ago.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could just follow up. I mean, I think one of the questions has been the durability of companies like yours to pay higher sports rights as others might come in, the Internet companies. I was just wondering if you think scaling up is important to
componenttext: Okay. If I could just follow up. I mean, I think one of the questions has been the durability of companies like yours to pay higher sports rights as others might come in, the Internet companies. I was just wondering if you think scaling up is important to be able to compete with that and compete in that future, or maybe that's less important for you guys as a strategic priority right now.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not so sure it's the future. I think, actually, it's the present. If we look at the IPL auction in India last year, we were competing very aggressively with Facebook in that auction. And we have a great platform there. It's a great platform for
componenttext: Well, I'm not so sure it's the future. I think, actually, it's the present. If we look at the IPL auction in India last year, we were competing very aggressively with Facebook in that auction. And we have a great platform there. It's a great platform for monetization. It's a great platform for reaching audience. And we were able to win that auction. But in all of these places, it's a question really of making choices, and that's why you don't have to say -- you don't have to be all in on every set of rights and pay whatever it takes. And I don't -- it doesn't really matter who's bidding. I mean, people have to make economic choices around the value of these rights, the value of these products. So we like our ability to compete across the board with these brands with a variety and the diversity of rights that I think we've proven ourselves in terms of being able to put together really compelling packages there, but it's never a question of all or nothing. You have to make choices, and sometimes, you don't think something is worth as much as somebody else does, and you push the business in a -- or steer the business in a different direction.

componenttextpreview: Two questions, John. On the Disney deal, now that the tax reform has been signed into law, can you update us at all on the dividend payment that New Fox will make in the 21st Century at the close for the spin and then how that relates to sort of the balan
componenttext: Two questions, John. On the Disney deal, now that the tax reform has been signed into law, can you update us at all on the dividend payment that New Fox will make in the 21st Century at the close for the spin and then how that relates to sort of the balance sheet or the debt level at New Fox once this is all closed? I know there's still moving pieces, but now that we have the tax law signed, I was hoping you could give us some clarity. And then just at the risk of beating Thursday Night Football to death, you guys have invested a lot in ad tech to try to monetize viewers better. But certainly, the consensus to you is that the ad revenues on the NFL are flat to down looking forward given the ratings trajectory. I'm just wondering if you have a different perspective based on what you've been able to do with TrueX and other products to try to monetize large live audiences and maybe we're being too conservative in our outlook on the advertising side of the NFL.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben. It's John, I'll start. Look, it depends on how you value New Fox to answer this question. But in my own mind, the tax liability that will result from the spin of New Fox is somewhere in the plus or minus zone now with tax reform in of $6 bill
componenttext: Thanks, Ben. It's John, I'll start. Look, it depends on how you value New Fox to answer this question. But in my own mind, the tax liability that will result from the spin of New Fox is somewhere in the plus or minus zone now with tax reform in of $6 billion. And remember, there is always, as part of the deal, a minimum debt level at New Fox of $6.5 billion. So as a result, I think you should assume we will be making a minimum distribution, and the spread between the tax and the debt is accomplished or compensated for by an adjustment to the exchange ratio. So -- and every -- look, you pick a point on what you think the equity trading value is for every dollar that, that market value moves one way or another, it's about $425 million of cash tax.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2018
componenttextpreview: And then on the point about advertising, look, I think we're making really good progress on nonlinear advertising and new advertising formats in the linear stream as well. So I feel -- we feel pretty good about that. I think, clearly, the ratings did impa
componenttext: And then on the point about advertising, look, I think we're making really good progress on nonlinear advertising and new advertising formats in the linear stream as well. So I feel -- we feel pretty good about that. I think, clearly, the ratings did impact revenue. The number of impressions we can deliver to advertisers is always going to be something that we have to do well or -- what we do with it. We have some pretty difficult comparisons, as John mentioned, in this year-on-year period, but we actually feel reasonably good about it. And I think, actually, the promise of streaming environment is one there -- where even in -- sort of in linear broadcasting on sports, for example, having nonlinear, really data-driven advertising platform sitting underneath that and being able to monetize that audience is hugely attractive. And we see that starting to bear fruit, but it's still not an enormous part of the audience that's consuming on linear product on digital streaming platforms. So that's something that as that grows, we think that the yields from a minute-by-minute, customer-by-customer basis will continue to improve. We certainly see that, for example, in the Hulu streams where we just have dramatically better monetization on Hulu-owned and operated apps than we do, for example, on the traditional MVPD distribution, which is something that is encouraging in terms of leveling off and equalizing those over the next number of years, which we think is very possible.
